# William Francis Deegan

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Deeganstone_crop.jpg/225px-
Deeganstone_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Deeganstone_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Deeganstone_crop.jpg "Enlarge")

Memorial at E 138th Street

**William Francis Deegan** (December 28, 1882 – April 3, 1932) was an
[architect](/wiki/Architect "Architect"), organizer of the [American
Legion](/wiki/American_Legion "American Legion"), [major](/wiki/Major "Major")
in the [Army Corps of Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers
"United States Army Corps of Engineers"), and
[Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") political leader in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City
"New York City").[1][2]

##
Biography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=William_Francis_Deegan&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Biography")]

He was born on December 28, 1882 to Irish immigrants. He studied architecture
at [Cooper Union](/wiki/Cooper_Union "Cooper Union") and at age 35 served in
[World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") as a staff officer in the
[105th Field
Artillery](/w/index.php?title=105th_Field_Artillery&action=edit&redlink=1
"105th Field Artillery \(page does not exist\)").[3]

Deegan later joined the [United States Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "United States Army
Corps of Engineers") as a [major](/wiki/Major "Major"), where he supervised
the construction of military bases in the New York area under the command of
[General](/wiki/General "General") [George W.
Goethals](/wiki/George_W._Goethals "George W. Goethals").[1] After the war he
helped organize the [American Legion](/wiki/American_Legion "American Legion")
in 1919, advancing to State Commander in 1921.[1] Deegan worked as an
architect at a number of distinguished firms, including [McKim, Mead, and
White](/wiki/McKim,_Mead,_and_White "McKim, Mead, and White"); [Post, Magnicke
and Franke](/w/index.php?title=Post,_Magnicke_and_Franke&action=edit&redlink=1
"Post, Magnicke and Franke \(page does not exist\)"); and [Starrett and Van
Vieck](/w/index.php?title=Starrett_and_Van_Vieck&action=edit&redlink=1
"Starrett and Van Vieck \(page does not exist\)").[1][3] Later in life he held
a number of political positions, most of them in [the Bronx](/wiki/The_Bronx
"The Bronx").[1] Deegan was President of the [Bronx Chamber of
Commerce](/w/index.php?title=Bronx_Chamber_of_Commerce&action=edit&redlink=1
"Bronx Chamber of Commerce \(page does not exist\)") until the chamber grew
critical of Mayor [Jimmy Walker](/wiki/Jimmy_Walker "Jimmy Walker"), at which
point he resigned. In 1928, Mayor Walker appointed him [Tenement House
Commissioner](/wiki/Tenement_House_Commissioner "Tenement House Commissioner")
of New York City – a post he was to hold for the rest of his life[1] – and in
1930, Chairman of the [Mayor's Committee on Receptions to Distinguished
Guests](/wiki/Mayor%27s_Committee_on_Receptions_to_Distinguished_Guests
"Mayor's Committee on Receptions to Distinguished Guests"), or "official
greeter", a job in which he was preceded by his friend [Rodman
Wanamaker](/wiki/Rodman_Wanamaker "Rodman Wanamaker") and eventually succeeded
by [Grover Whalen](/wiki/Grover_Whalen "Grover Whalen").

Deegan died following an [appendectomy](/wiki/Appendectomy "Appendectomy") on
April 3, 1932.[2][3]

##
Legacy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=William_Francis_Deegan&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Legacy")]

At the time of his death, a new road was being built from the [Triborough
Bridge](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Bridge "Robert F. Kennedy Bridge") to the
[Grand Concourse](/wiki/Grand_Concourse_\(Bronx\) "Grand Concourse
\(Bronx\)"). This was renamed and expanded in 1956[1] into the [Major Deegan
Expressway](/wiki/Major_Deegan_Expressway "Major Deegan Expressway") section
of [I-87](/wiki/I-87_\(NY\) "I-87 \(NY\)") in the Bronx, which retains his
name.
